title: Rapper E-40 says 'racial bias' is to blame for ejection from Warriors-Kings playoff
description: The Sacramento Kings say the team is currently investigating the incident and the exact reason why the rapper was removed from the arena.

title: The world's fastest marathoner wanted Boston under his belt. The day had other plans.
description: Turns out, Mondays can suck for everyone.

title: How disappearing ice in Antarctica threatens the U.S.
description: Galveston, Texas has some of the fastest sea level rise in the world. To protect the city, engineers need to know how fast ice in West Antarctica will melt. Scientists are racing to figure it out.

title: Outrage grows over the shooting of a Black teenager who rang the wrong doorbell
description: Ralph Yarl, a 16-year-old high school junior, was shot by a homeowner after he went to the wrong address to pick up his younger brothers, his family says. The shooter has not yet been charged.

title: Speaker McCarthy outlines GOP debt limit plan, Democrats pan demands as extreme
description: Talks over raising the nation's borrowing authority are stalled so House Speaker McCarthy says GOP will vote on their own plan. Democrats say adding demands to avoid a historic default is reckless.

title: Officials have identified the four people who died in an Alabama shooting
description: Another 28 people were injured. Authorities have given few details about the weekend shooting during a birthday party, including if they knew of any suspects or a motive.

title: Congress returns from recess with a big to-do list
description: Addressing the fallout of a leak of classified intelligence documents and drafting legislation to avoid a default on the nation's credit limit are just a few items on Congress' to-do list.

title: Why Frank Ocean's long-anticipated Coachella performance was a mixed bag
description: Frank Ocean closed the opening weekend of the music festival Coachella. He was originally slated to headline in 2020, but the show was postponed due to COVID.

title: Latest on Ukraine: Russia's prisoners, Brazil's diplomacy, the fight for Bakhmut
description: Catch up on key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

title: A Spanish athlete spent 500 days alone in a cave — for science
description: Beatriz Flamini was 48 when she entered the Granada cave in November 2021, and 50 when she emerged on Friday. Her experiment aims to shed light on the physical and mental effects of isolation.

title: This floating ocean garbage is home to a surprising amount of life from the coasts
description: A study of plastic trash hauled out of the Pacific Ocean found that most of it had been colonized by coastal life that was thriving right next to species that normally live in the open sea.

title: Watch Live: Space X to launch Starship, the world's largest rocket
description: The 400-foot-tall, stainless steel Starship could one day shuttle humans to the moon and Mars, and prove critical to launching Starlink satellites. But getting the rocket to fly is no easy feat.

title: 12-year-olds can't buy cigarettes — but they can work in tobacco fields
description: Child labor rules in agriculture are looser than those in other industries, even for tasks that are dangerous. For all tobacco laborers, but especially kids, the work can cause nicotine poisoning.

title: Russia sentences opposition activist Vladimir Kara-Murza to 25 years in prison
description: Kara-Murza's sentence is the harshest prison term delivered yet to a government opponent since the Kremlin launched its war in Ukraine in February 2022.

title: Rival military factions battle for control of Sudan — dozens of civilians are killed
description: NPR's Leila Fadel talks to former U.S. State Department special envoy for the Horn of Africa Jeffrey Feltman about the bloody struggle in Sudan between the army and rival paramilitary forces.

title: Why two military rivals are in a 'fight to the death' in Sudan
description: Fierce fighting has spread outside Sudan's capital, Khartoum, and across the country, as the forces of two warring military leaders battle for control.

title: Joshua Wong sentenced in another Hong Kong activism case
description: Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong was sentenced Monday to 3 months in prison for breaching court bans on disclosing personal information about a police officer during 2019 anti-government protests.

title: Supreme Court looks at whether Medicare and Medicaid were overbilled under fraud law
description: Arguments on Tuesday center on a powerful tool for fighting fraud in government contracts and programs. The case examines whether major pharmacies knowingly overcharged Medicare and Medicaid.

title: Teen with life-threatening depression finally found hope. Then insurance cut her off
description: Despite laws that say mental health care should be paid for on a par with other medical care, health insurance stopped covering the care a suicidal teen needed before she was stable.

title: Jamil was struggling after his daughter had a stroke. Then a doctor pulled up a chair
description: In 2015, Dr. Mark Petersen shared difficult news about the treatment plan for Jamil Zaki's fragile newborn daughter. But instead of delivering the news and getting back to work, he pulled up a chair.

title: Netflix delayed the live reunion of 'Love is Blind', but didn't say why
description: The season four reunion of the hit reality show was supposed to premiere live at 8 p.m. ET, but it wasn't until about 9:30 p.m. that Netflix said it was having difficulties.

title: Former NBA star Shawn Kemp is charged with 1st-degree assault in a March shooting
description: Kemp said he was shot at first after he tracked down his stolen cell phone and confronted the person he presumed had it. Kemp was released from jail and not initially charged after the incident.

title: Residents near Indiana warehouse fire may have asbestos on their property, EPA says
description: Officials said some of the material that burned at a former plastic recycling plant in Richmond, Ind., contained asbestos, a known carcinogen. The EPA tells people not to touch any debris they find.
